Tier 1 'Support to EIF National Implementation Arrangements (NIAs
NIAs)' project template D ENHANCED INTEGRATED FRAMEWORK | TIER 1 'SUPPORT TO NIAs' PROJECT PROPOSAL SECTION I: Summary Page | I.1 Project title

focus. I.2 Category of project | Tier 1. I.3 Grant recipient entity | Name, nature (public, private, other), national or international. I.4 Implementing entity (if different from grant recipient entity) | Name, nature (public, private, other), national or international. I.5 Project duration

indicating expected start date. I.6 Total project costs
6 Total project costs | In US$. I.7 EIF funding sought

SECTION II: Situation Analysis II.1
overview of the implementation of the AfT and trade development agenda
trade development agenda in the country, including any problems/difficulties that are being encountered. II.2
project will contribute to trade mainstreaming; How the project will contribute to inter-ministerial and donor coordination

Government contributions What are the government contributions (financial, in-kind (premises, vehicles, overheads, insurance, etc.) and complementary activities necessary to achieve the results of the project) and other demonstrations of government commitment
expected that government contributions increase over the course of the project (if multi-year

SECTION IV: Risk and Mitigation Strategy IV.1 Identify risks for project delivery and/or project results Risks should be categorized into those that are integral to the project, i.e., those that the project design can address, and other risks outside of the project and outside of the influence of the project. IV.2 Describe how the risks under Section IV.1 will be mitigated For risks integral to the project, show how the project design intends to mitigate the risks; for risks outside of the project, describe what mitigation strategy the government might have. SECTION V: Project Implementation Arrangements V.1
nature of the implementing entity, experience in providing services as requested, references, etc. V.2 National ownership
project will ensure national ownership. V.3 NIU implementation arrangements (if applicable
V.3 NIU implementation arrangements (if applicable) Describe
internal supervision arrangements adopted by the NIU while implementing and/or coordinating activities to be undertaken by other

Fiduciary responsibilities Organization of the project and succinct description of roles and functions of key staff assuming fiduciary responsibilities (line ministry, FP, NIU, NIU Coordinator, accounting/finance officer) (see National Fiduciary Responsibility Framework (including reporting and control mechanisms
Financial and fiduciary management Detailed description of procedures for recruitment, procurement, subcontracts, accounting, etc
Audit requirements Description of internal audit procedures and external audit requirements
Monitoring and evaluation (MAndE) Summarize the MAndE mechanism of the project, including
SECTION VI: Logical Framework, Work Plan and Budget Project Implementation Arrangements

2 Notes: Salary contributions and other recurrent costs
A project may support salaries on a country-specific basis provided that a detailed justification/explanation is given and demonstrates how such salary contributions shall be temporary in nature. Therefore, the section on sustainability in Sections III
address the project's graduation strategy with reference to the salaries and how the sustainability of the results is ensured in light of the graduation strategy

NIUs) may be composed of government staff and/or externally recruited experts. In any case, a justification for the composition should be provided. Governments are encouraged to assign staff to the NIUs on an appropriate basis or to release them so that they may compete for positions in, or associated with, the NIUs. All staff associated with

project cannot fund severance payments.
Vehicles and other capital items The purchase of a vehicle may be granted, but a justification
Payment of import duties and taxes Governments are requested to afford the EIF programme the same treatment they afford to international organizations present in their countries
